lg.l: I sing the man of wondrous skill,
The best that ever blew a quill,
Or keepit gimmers,22 n. female sheep between first and second shearing. on a hill

By Tay33 The Tay originates in the West, winds across the Highlands and eventually flows to its mouth at the Firth of Tay. or Tweed,44 Running through the Borders, the River Tweed forms the boundary between Scotland and England.

Or Irvine water,55 The river Irvine flows through southwest Scotland, running near Kilmarnock, down to the coastal town of Irvine and is featured in many of Turnbull's poems. Cf. “Ode VII: To Irvine Water” and "Irvine Water" in Poetical Essays (1788). smooth and still,
Wha now is dead.
Ay when he play’d, the sheep advanc’d,
The yowes and lams thegither danc’d,
The awkward cattle lap and pranc’d,
Wi’ clumsy speed;
And lightfoot look’d like ane entranc’d,
To hear his reed.
The lasses gather’d him about,
And ilka gaping kintra lout66 n. country bumpkin.
Led on the dance, an unco77 adj. unknown, unfamiliar, strange. rout,
And through the reel,
They toss’d the hizzies,88 n. disparaging name for women, esp. young frivolous women. in and out,
And gart them squeel.
He fidg’d, and leugh, to see the fun,
Cry’d, till’t again, I’m scarce begun;
He wha a bonny lass wad won,
Maun wallup here,
Then up he play’d the cutty-gun,99 n. short tobacco pipe.
Their hearts to cheer.
What signifies a piper’s drone,
Or fiddle, for to play upon,
’Bout ilka smooth Italian tone
Mak nae mair bustle,
Willie1010 Pastoral shepherd and speaker in Spenser’s The Shepheardes Calender. cou’d gar them a’ stan’ yon’
Just wi’ a whistle.
Beside his elbow stood a bicker,1111 n. wooden drinking cup.
For he made ay his mouthfu’ sicker,
And for to mak him play the quicker,
They fill’d his cap;
He leugh and toutit up the liquor
Out ilka drap.
This rais’d him to a canty key,
And gart his whistle sound wi’ glee;
An unco merry bod was he,
When ance turn’d sou,
And nane wi’ better grace cou’d prie,
A lasses’ mou’.
He had right mony a pawky tale,
To tell outo’er a capfu’ ale;
His canty jokes cou’d never fail,
In time o’ need,
To cheer the heart, be’t sick or hale,
But now he’s dead.
He had an unco head o’ wit,
Was never noddle sure like it;
He was for Priest or Doctor fit,
And weil did ken a’
The Latin Grammar, ilka bit,
As far as Penna.1212 n. Latin for contour feather, that is, a pen.
He faught, but finile met wi’ scars,
For they were only wordy wars;
He kent the order o’ the stars,
And eke the moon,
Cou’d tell, in Venus. or in Mars,
Whate’er was done.

Not Ramsey,1313 Allan Ramsay (1686-1758), the Scottish poet for whose play The Gentle Shepherd Turnbull wrote a prologue. nor the canty Chiel,1414 Robert Semphill (1596-1663), whose “Lament for Habbie Simpson” was the first poem in the “Standard Habbie” meter later used by both Robert Fergusson and Burns.
Wha sang Hab Simson’s life sae weil,
Nor yet the Bard o’ Gilbert fiel’,1515 William Hamilton of Gilbertfield (1665-1751), who wrote a modern verse life of William Wallace.
Nor Sawny Pope,1616 The poet Alexander Pope (1688-1744), notable for the ease with which he claimed to write when young: “I lisp’d in numbers.”
Cou’d faster up Parnassus1717 Home of the Muses. speel,1818 v. clamber, climb.
To reach the top.
Of a’ sic qualities as thae,
He was possess’d, and mony mae,
The neebours said that he cou’d spae,
And fortunes tell;
I doubt it, but if it was sae,
He kent himsel’.
